nodes.title: II.2. Superficial structures: Primarily funerary superstructure
Oral tradition
nodes.body: According to local drok pa’brog pa, MarrongDmar rong consists of ancient remains.

nodes.title: East group
nodes.body: The three east group structures form a row 28 m long. These structures are not aligned in the cardinal directions. They are made of a white calcareous rock and a grayish volcanic (?) rock. All three funerary structures of the east group are overgrown with nettles.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS2
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS2 (5.1 m x 4.2 m) has a forward flank elevated about 1.2 m above the downhill slope (34.977΄ / 56.925΄). Small portions of coherently built side walls are extant. These double-course walls (70 cm thick) consist of three layers of stones and attain a height of 30 cm.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS3
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS3 (5.6 m x 4.4 m) has a forward flank 1.5 m in height and a rear wall flush with the slope (34.975΄ / 56.922΄). The double-course side wall (around 70 cm thick) fragments are composed of four layers of stones and reach 35 cm in height.

nodes.title: West group
nodes.body: The west group of funerary structures is situated 17.5 m west of the east group. These structures are mostly made of a different type of rock (igneous?).

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS4
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS4 (5.2 m x 4.3 m) has small portions of all four walls intact (34.951΄ / 56.832΄). The forward flank has a height of about 1.5 m.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS5
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS5 (6.2 m x 5.3 m) has parts of all four walls intact (34.951 / 56.831). The forward flank has a height of about 1.5 m, while the rear wall is set 20 cm below the slope. One double-course side wall segment is approximately 1 m thick.

nodes.title: Funerary Structure FS6
nodes.body: Funerary structure FS6 (7.3 m x 4.7 m) appears to be aligned in the cardinal directions. Despite changes to he slope having damaged the upper portion of the structure, its lower part is the best preserved structure at MarrongDmar rong. The corner where the south and west walls are joined is intact, showing that FS6 was a neatly built quadrate structure. This corner is made up of three vertical courses of masonry and has a height of 30 cm. Small fragments of blue and red slate are found on the structure, which possibly may have been part of its subsurface architecture.
